## Clinical Case: Case number 19078

### Clinical History
A 49-year-old premenopausal woman presented to the gynaecologist with complaints of a painful right breast lump, which had started two weeks before. She had no known history of significant medical conditions. The physician ordered a bilateral mammography (Figure 1) and a breast ultrasound (Figure 2).

### Imaging Findings
A mediolateral oblique tomosynthesis view of the right breast revealed a 7 cm asymmetry in the upper outer quadrant (UOQ) (Figure 1). Ultrasound showed a hypoechoic palpable mass (Figure 2) with indistinct margins and no vascularity. No suspicious axillary lymph nodes were shown. The breast lesion was assigned a BI-RADS 4C category, and a US-guided vacuum-assisted biopsy (10G) was performed. The diagnostic workup was completed with contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM) after the biopsy (Figures 3a and 3b), which demonstrated a 7 cm non-mass enhancement in the UOQ of the right breast.Histopathological examination revealed no evidence of malignancy. The tissue showed features consistent with sclerosing lymphocytic mastitis, including a dense lymphocytic infiltrate, collagenised stroma, and a thickened basal membrane.The findings were reviewed in a multidisciplinary team with pathologists, gynaecologists and radiologists. Although the initial imaging findings were highly suspicious for malignancy (BI-RADS 4C), retrospective analysis revealed that the clinical and imaging features were concordant with the pathological diagnosis. Upon further review of the patient��s history, there was no evidence of diabetes or autoimmune disease. However, laboratory tests showed chronic hyperglycaemia, with HbA1c values between 5.8% and 6.1%. She was referred to an endocrinologist and underwent an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), which revealed glucose levels of 89 mg/dl at 0 minutes and 183 mg/dl at 120 minutes. Her BMI was 30.85 kg/m2.Based on these findings, a conservative approach was adopted, with dietary intervention aimed at glycaemic control. At the six-month clinical follow-up, she reported no pain or palpable lump in the breast. OGTT values had improved to 83 mg/dl at 0 minutes and 137 mg/dl at 120 minutes, with an HbA1c of 5.4%. Follow-up breast imaging one year after biopsy showed complete resolution of the focal asymmetry (Figure 4).

### Discussion
BackgroundLymphocytic mastitis is an uncommon fibroinflammatory breast lesion with an unclear aetiology [1�C3]. It is more frequently observed in patients with poorly controlled long-standing type 1 diabetes (also known as diabetic mastopathy) [1�C4]. Exogenous insulin administration may trigger inflammatory reactions in the breast [1,3]. Alternatively, the secondary autoimmune effects of the accumulation of glucose in the extracellular connective tissue are thought to induce an immune response [4] that could be a possible mechanism to explain the association of lymphocytic mastitis with type 2 diabetes, as reported herein. However, this illness has also been described in association with other autoimmune or endocrine disorders, and in patients without any such comorbidities [2�C4].Clinical PerspectiveThis condition more commonly affects premenopausal women between 30 and 50 years of age [1,3,4], and is rarely observed in men with gynecomastia [1,3]. Clinically, it presents as one or more asymptomatic, firm breast masses, varying in size and location [1�C4]. A predilection for the subareolar region has been reported [3,4]. Inflammatory signs at breast physical examination are usually absent [3,4].Imaging PerspectiveThe most common mammographic finding of lymphocytic mastitis is asymmetry underlying a palpable mass, generally between 3 and 6 cm in diameter [1,3,6]. Lymphocytic mastitis at mammography may disclose no findings, being distinctive for the absence of masses, calcifications and spiculated lesions [1,3,5,6].Ultrasound often shows hypoechoic areas with irregular margins and marked posterior acoustic shadowing, caused by fibrosis. This prominent shadowing is characteristic and often more pronounced than that seen in neoplastic lesions. Although it is more commonly associated with malignancy, it can also be observed in benign lesions with a high degree of fibrosis [1,3,6].Although MRI findings are not specific for lymphocytic mastitis, they may aid in establishing the diagnosis and confirming the benign nature of the lesion [5]. At MRI, lymphocytic mastitis most often demonstrates gradual and persistent non-mass enhancement, but it has no specific MRI pattern, and it may disclose no findings [3�C6]. To our knowledge, contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM) findings of lymphocytic mastitis have not been previously reported. We present the first documented case showing this entity as a non-mass enhancement on CEM. Our findings correlate well with previously reported MRI-based studies [5,6].OutcomeCore needle biopsy is the preferred diagnostic method [1�C4]. Clinical and imaging findings of lymphocytic mastitis are nonspecific, often overlapping breast cancer features. Therefore, this diagnosis requires histological proof with core needle biopsy, multidisciplinary correlation, and clinical and imaging follow-up. Excisional biopsy should be reserved for cases with reasonable doubt and suspicion of malignancy, especially considering the high recurrence rates reported after surgical excision [1,3].A conservative, observational approach is initially recommended to avoid unnecessary surgery [1,3]. Follow-up should include annual clinical review and imaging with mammography and/or ultrasound [1]. Marking the biopsy site with a clip can help to confirm adequate biopsy sampling and facilitate future monitoring. Following an excision, recurrence rates can be as high as 32% [3]. There is no evidence to suggest that lymphocytic mastitis increases the risk of the development of breast cancer [3].Take Home Message / Teaching PointsDiagnosing lymphocytic mastopathy can be challenging due to its similarities with breast carcinoma [1,3]. The diagnosis is particularly difficult in patients without type 1 diabetes or autoimmune diseases. Multidisciplinary integration of clinical and multimodal imaging findings is of paramount importance to avoid repeated biopsies and unnecessary excisional procedures.Follow-up with imaging��including mammography and ultrasound, CEM, or MRI��is important, as lymphocytic mastitis may be a self-limited disease, as demonstrated in our report. However, recurrence in the same or the contralateral breast is possible, highlighting the need for continued surveillance.

### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Breast carcinoma
B. Granulomatous mastitis
C. Lymphocytic mastopathy
D. Traumatic lesions
E. Panarteritis nodosa

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "C", "reasoning": "Imaging suggested a suspicious fibrous mass, but core biopsy showed dense lymphocytic infiltrate, collagenised stroma and thickened basement membrane\u2014histologic features diagnostic of lymphocytic mastopathy (diabetic mastopathy). The association with impaired glucose metabolism and clinical/imaging resolution with conservative management further supports this benign diagnosis over carcinoma, granulomatous mastitis, trauma, or vasculitis."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 10128

### Clinical History
A 43-year-old gentleman presented with neurological symptoms and CT of the head was abnormal with signs of hydrocephalus. Endoscopic third ventriculostomy relieved the pressure symptoms of hydrocephalus and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis. Further neurosurgery was not possible and the patient underwent radical radiotherapy with good response.

### Imaging Findings
The differential diagnosis of masses in the region of pineal gland includes (their distinguishing radiological features are given in brackets) [1];?	Pineal cyst (well circumscribed fluid density lesions)?	Primary Pineal tumours (radiological features vary depending upon grade of the lesion. Low grade pineocytomas are better defined and high grade pineoblastomas are poorly defined. As these originate from pineocytes, the masses are usually calcified)?	Germ cell tumours (contrast enhancing soft tissue density masses and intrinsic calcification is uncommon, these tend to engulf normal pineal gland calcification)?	Secondary metastases (in the majority of cases there is evidence of primary disease elswhere)?	Vascular lesions (radiographically distinct lesions with no soft tissue mass effect with possible associated dilated vessels or vascular aneurysms)

### Discussion
A 43-year-old previously fit and healthy gentleman presented with progressively worsening symptoms of early morning headaches, nausea, dizziness and vision blurring. CT examination showed space occupied lesion. MRI revealed enhancing pineal mass with signs of hydrocephalus. He underwent endoscopic third ventriculostomy, and a biopsy was taken. Symptoms of hydrocephalus resolved and the pathology confirmed WHO grade IV Pineoblastoma (Ki67 >40%).Futher surgical resection was not feasible due to operative risks. MRI of the spine did not show any abnormality and lumber puncture revealed highly suspicious for malignant cells �C Chang stage M3. Serum tumour markers, AFP and HCG levels were normal. A diagnosis of high grade pineoblastoma was made and the patient was offered craniospinal irradiation. He received 40.8 Gray in 24 fractions to cranio-spinal axis and 15.3 Gray in 9 fractions as a boost to the pineal tumour. He developed alopecia and grade 1 scalp erythema. Soon after completion of his tumour, he was admitted with sepsis secondary to bilateral pneumonias which was treated accordingly. He made a full recovery. Post treatment, he was also found to have low cortisol and increased ACTH levels. Endocrinology opinion was obtained and it was felt that the picture was consistent with partial hypoadrenalism likely secondary to exogenous use of steroids. There was no significant evidence of hypopituitrism. He was commenced on steroid replacement and recovered very well. Repeat MRI three months after completion of radiotherapy showed good response to the treatment.Pineal region tumours are rare, <1% of all intracranial tumours (in children, 3-8%) [2]. Germ cell tumours are more common in this region. Pineocytomas are more common than Pineoblastoma, which are extremely rare. Maximum possible surgery is treatment of choice. Radiotherpay is used adjuvantly and radically in case of residual disease post surgery [3]. In case of metastasis (like in this case as CSF was positive for malignant cells), craniospinal irradiation (CSI) is treatment of choice. It is associated with side effects e.g. tiredness, emesis, skin reaction, alopecia, bone marrow suppression, headaches, sleep and memory disturbance. It can also affect the pituitary function due to some unavoidable dose to the pituitary gland. The patient needs to be under regular follow up with surveillance images. The prognosis depends on histological type, size of the tumour and extent of disease at presentation [4]. Surgical resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy results in median survival of 20 months [2].

### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Meningioma
B. Dermoid
C. Tectal Glioma
D. Intracranial Germ cell tumour
E. Pineoblastoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "E", "reasoning": "Biopsy confirmed a WHO grade IV pineal-region tumour with high proliferative index (Ki-67 >40%), hydrocephalus, CSF positive for malignant cells (Chang M3), and treatment with craniospinal irradiation \u2014 findings diagnostic of pineoblastoma rather than meningioma, dermoid, tectal glioma, or germ cell tumour."}

### Clinical History
A 27-year-old nulliparous female came for her first antenatal scan at 32 weeks of gestation with no prior early antenatal scans. She presented with a bilobed abdominal contour seen externally as two distinct bulges with a central vertical depression. No earlier imaging had been done.

### Imaging Findings
An ultrasound examination revealed a thin central septum partially dividing the uterus into two hemicavities. The amniotic sac was seen occupying both the uterine hemicavities. The foetus was viable, with the foetal abdomen and lower extremities seen in the right hemicavity, and the foetal head and upper extremities extending into the left hemicavity across the central septum (Figures 1 and 2). Nearly two-thirds of the placenta was implanted on the left side of the central septum, with the rest of it implanted on the anterior wall of the left hemicavity (Figure 3). No vascularity was detected in the uterine septum on Doppler ultrasound.

B. Gravid didelphys uterus with partial fusion
C. Gravid septate uterus with septal placental implantation
D. Gravid arcuate uterus with exaggerated indentation
E. Gravid uterus with intrauterine synechiae or band

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "C", "reasoning": "Ultrasound demonstrates a thin, midline avascular septum partially dividing the endometrial cavity with the gestational sac/amnion extending into both hemicavities and placental tissue implanted on the septum. These findings are characteristic of a septate uterus with septal placental implantation. Bicornuate or didelphys uteri would show an external fundal cleft or separate uterine horns/cervices, an arcuate uterus has only a mild fundal indentation, and intrauterine synechiae/bands are acquired and have different appearance/clinical history; the avascular persistent midline septum best fits a septate uterus."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 19090

### Clinical History
A 74-year-old woman presented for a breast ultrasound, clinically indicated due to the presence of a solitary, mildly palpable nodular area near the scar of a previous breast resection performed several years earlier for a benign condition (intraductal papilloma). She denied any relevant associated symptoms.

### Imaging Findings
Ultrasound examination revealed, in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, a superficial hypoechoic lesion measuring approximately 20 mm in diameter, with well-defined, lobulated margins (Figure 1a) and minimal internal vascularity on colour Doppler (Figure 1b), located adjacent to the previous surgical scar. No other significant or suspicious findings were noted in either breast. Bilateral axillary lymph nodes appeared mildly hyperplastic, but with preserved echo structure.In view of the imaging findings and clinical context, an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy of the lesion was performed. Histological analysis of the breast tissue revealed extensive stromal fibrosis with a nodular infiltrate of small B and T lymphocytes and a moderate number of CD138-positive plasma cells, which showed polyclonal expression for kappa and lambda light chains. Eosinophilic granulocytes were also present. Immunohistochemistry showed over 50 IgG4-positive plasma cells per high-power field (HPF) in multiple fields, raising suspicion for IgG4-related disease, especially when considered together with clinical and laboratory findings. No carcinoma was found, and the lesion was classified as B2 (benign).The patient underwent ultrasound (Figures 2a and 2b) and mammographic (Figures 3a and 3b) follow-up at 6 months, which confirmed the presence of the vascularised hypoechoic lesion with well-defined, lobulated margins. She was subsequently referred for a specialised rheumatologic consultation.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. IgG4-related breast disease
B. Invasive ductal carcinoma
C. Papillomatosis
D. Mass-forming ductal carcinoma in situ
E. Lymphoproliferative disorder

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "Core biopsy shows dense stromal fibrosis with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, numerous CD138+ plasma cells with polyclonal kappa/lambda expression and >50 IgG4+ plasma cells/HPF \u2014 histologic features characteristic of IgG4-related disease. Imaging (well-defined, lobulated hypoechoic lesion adjacent to scar) and absence of malignant epithelial cells on biopsy argue against invasive carcinoma, DCIS, or papillomatosis. Monoclonality would be expected in a lymphoproliferative disorder, which is not present. Therefore the most likely diagnosis is IgG4-related breast disease."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 10146

### Clinical History
62-year-old male patient presented with soft tissue swelling at the volar side of the wrist. There was no history of trauma and no reference of neurological signs. History of colon cancer was present.

### Imaging Findings
A 62-year-old male patient, with a slow-growing mass of the right wrist, was referred to the radiology department for evaluation. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed in the axial and sagittal planes. An oval-shaped mass of 48 x 12 x 10 mm was depicted in the carpal tunnel. The tumor showed low to intermediate signal on T1 weighted images(Fig.1a) and inhomogeneous predominantly low signal on T2 (Fig.1b). After intravenous contrast administration (Fig.1c), the tumor showed inhomogeneous enhancement (Fig.2). Peripheral enhancement extends around an ulnar sided flexor tendon. The tumor was surgically excised and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Fibroma of the tendon sheath.
B. Ganglion cyst
C. Giant-cell tumor of tendon sheath
D. Fibrous histiocytoma
E. Nodular fasciitis

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: C

Reasoning: A well-defined, tendon-sheath–related mass in the carpal tunnel that is low–intermediate on T1 and predominantly low on T2 with inhomogeneous enhancement is most consistent with a localized tenosynovial giant-cell tumor (giant-cell tumor of tendon sheath). Ganglion cyst would be T2-bright with only rim enhancement; fibroma of tendon sheath is possible but tends to be smaller and more uniformly very low on T2 from dense collagen; nodular fasciitis and fibrous histiocytoma have different clinical behavior and signal patterns. The location around the flexor tendon and the described signal/enhancement pattern favor GCTTS.

## Clinical Case: Case number 10186

### Clinical History
A 38-year-old woman was admitted to the emergency department with left quadrants abdominal pain. Past medical history was unremarkable.Physical examination revealed abdominal tenderness. Laboratory tests were abnormal with leukocytosis and the patient was febrile.Abdominal ultrasound and CT were performed.

### Imaging Findings
Transverse and longitudinal sonograms of the left flank show a hypoechoic lesion with no vascularization and adjacent hyperechoic fat. The lesion presents a small anechoic (liquid) component.Enhanced axial CT examination demonstrates a well-defined hypodense mesenteric cystic mass, with fluid-fluid level due to different liquid contents (ranging from the attenuation of water to that of fat). There is adjacent fat stranding and peripheral enhancement.Complete surgical excision was performed.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Lymphangioma with inflammatory changes
B. Enteric duplication cyst
C. Non-pancreatic pseudocyst
D. Mesothelial cyst
E. Enteric cyst

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "The CT shows a mesenteric cystic mass with a fluid\u2013fluid level including fat-attenuation material, which is characteristic of chylous content seen in lymphatic malformations. The lesion is avascular on US and the surrounding fat stranding and peripheral enhancement indicate secondary inflammatory/infectious change. Enteric duplication cysts are typically contiguous with bowel and show a gut wall signature; mesothelial (simple) cysts are usually unilocular fluid-density without fat components; non-pancreatic pseudocyst would have a history of pancreatitis/trauma. Thus the most likely diagnosis is lymphangioma with inflammatory changes."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 10280

### Clinical History
A 65 year old man with previous coronary bypass, hypertension and diabetes, was admitted with increasing mid chest pain radiating to the back, dysphagia and dyspnea. On clinical examination there were no relevant findings.Normal blood pressure, heart rate and temperature. Normal ECG and MNMs.Laboratory findings revealed type II respiratory failure.

### Imaging Findings
A chest radiography revealed a hazy opacity in the left lung base(Fig.1). Angio chest CT pointed out lower left lung bronchiectasis (Fig.2), no signs of pulmonary-thromboembolism, and a 3. 5 cm sized saccular aneurysm resulting from penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer in the mid third of the descending aorta (Fig.3, 4).24 hours later, while treated conservatively with large spectrum antibiotics, his condition worsened with tachycardia and hypotension.Endoscopy mentioned no significant hemorrhagic findings.Unenhanced CT revealed a bulge in the left antero-medial aspect of the descending thoracic aorta, effacement of the periaortic fat plane along with gas bubbles surrounding the aortic wall(Fig.5). Enhanced sequences showed these abnormalities related to an enlarged (4.2 cm sized) saccular aneurysm with hazy aortic wall, intramural air (Figs.6, 7) and revealed a small amount of contrast extravasation in the gastric fundus(Fig.8).The patient was submitted to an emergency surgical intervention with poor outcome, confirming the presence of an aortoesophageal fistula.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Mycotic aneurysm
B. Perigraft infection
C. Penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer
D. Infectious aortiitis
E. Aortoesophageal fistula

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
E. Aortoesophageal fistula

Reasoning: The saccular descending aortic aneurysm with new periaortic gas/intramural air, effacement of the periaortic fat plane and CT demonstration of contrast extravasation into the upper GI tract indicate communication between the aorta and the esophagus/gastric region. Clinical deterioration with hypotension and surgery confirming the defect further support an aortoesophageal fistula (secondary to erosion of the penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer/saccular aneurysm).

## Clinical Case: Case number 10653

### Clinical History
A 13-year-old female patient presented to her general practitioner with diffuse abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound was performed showing a large mass in the right adnexal area. She was otherwise healthy and all laboratory tests were within normal values but delta-4-androstenedione which was 6.73ng/dl (normal values: 0.46-3.39 ng/dl).

### Imaging Findings
Abdominal ultrasound reported a solid inhomogeneous mass occupying the right adnexal area. Transvaginal ultrasound was not indicated since the patient had no prior sexual relations.MRI was performed with the following sequences: axial T1 and T2-weighted images, sagittal and coronal T2-weighted images. Contrast-enhanced sequences were not obtained and antispasmodics were not administrated. The tumour originated in the right ovary as demonstrated by the beak sign measuring 7x6, 5x7cm with well-defined contours. The examination showed hypointense and isointense areas on the T1-weighted images. The T2-weighted sequences demonstrated intermediate-to-high signal intensity and a 14mm-cyst in the periphery. A small amount of ascites was noticed in the right ovarian fossa. The left ovary and the uterus were unremarkable. There were no pathologic lymph nodes.After surgical resection pathology confirmed the diagnosis of a poorly differentiated Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor (SLCT) with retiform areas.The patient was treated with chemotherapy (bleomycin, ethoposide and cisplatinum) and maintains SLCT 4-year-remission.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Granulosa cell tumour (adult and juvenile type)
B. Fibroma
C. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour
D. Sclerosing stromal cell tumour
E. Techoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "C", "reasoning": "Adolescent girl with a unilateral, well-defined solid adnexal mass producing androgens (elevated delta-4-androstenedione) and imaging showing a predominantly solid ovarian tumor with small cystic component\u2014all characteristic of a Sertoli\u2013Leydig cell tumor. Pathology confirmed a poorly differentiated SLCT with retiform areas, which matches option C."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 10827

Patient with a history of coeliac disease who presented with diffuse abdominal pain and weight loss of approximately 15 kg.First an ultrasound was performed which shows a concentric mural thickening of thesplenic flexure of the colon, without other notable findings. The Abdominal CT with contrast administration showed multiple hypodense nodules insubcutaneous tissue of mammary region, gluteal region and both thighs and some stranding of the subcutaneous tissue, probably due to inflammation secondary to foreign body reaction.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Subcutaneous fat nodules
B. Subcutaneous metastases
C. Multifocal subcutaneous neurofibromas
D. Subcutaneous air bubles
E. Oil bubbles self-injected by the patient.

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:

Reasoning: Multiple well-defined hypodense (fat-attenuation) nodules in subcutaneous locations typical for sites of cosmetic injections (breast, gluteal, thighs) with surrounding fat stranding consistent with a foreign-body/inflammatory reaction — classic for self-injected oil/silicone. Subcutaneous metastases or neurofibromas would be soft-tissue attenuation and often enhance; air bubbles have much lower (near–air) attenuation.

## Clinical Case: Case number 13960

### Clinical History
A 40-year-old woman with a known osteochondroma in the left distal tibial metaphysis consulted for a growing mass in the same ankle, with tenderness and posterior tibial nerve compression symptoms.

### Imaging Findings
Radiographs (Fig. 1) showed the osteochondroma and posterior noncalcified soft-tissue mass in the ankle. An ultrasound (Fig. 2) was performed revealing a solid soft-tissue mass, in close relationship with the posterior tibial nerve.MRI (Fig. 3) was performed showing an oval lesion within the Kager fat pad with intermediate to high signal intensity on T1W images and heterogeneous signal intensity on T2W images, with areas of both intermediate and high signal intensity. No high-flow vascular channels were noted. The mass showed diffuse contrast-enhancement. The lesion was adjacent to the posterior tibial cortex but not to the osteochondroma. There were no signs of medullary invasion. The posterior tibial nerve could be seen apparently entering the mass. This last feature suggested the possible diagnosis of a neurogenic tumour.Percutaneous biopsy of the lesion was performed and anatomopathological study revealed findings for an extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Lymphoma
B. Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
C. Synovial sarcoma
D. Neurogenic tumour
E. Extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "E", "reasoning": "Rapidly growing painful soft-tissue mass in a 40\u2011year\u2011old, heterogeneous T1/T2 signal with diffuse enhancement in the Kager fat pad and biopsy-proven diagnosis support extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma. ## Clinical Case: Case number 11532

### Clinical History
A 56-year-old man presented with fever and left flank pain.He had a history of horseshoe kidney and urolithiasis. He had no other relevant medical history.Emergency abdominal ultrasound was performed.

### Imaging Findings
US (Fig. 1) shows a lobulated predominately cystic mass with thick wall and internal septa located in the left renal sinus.Dynamic 64-MDCT of the lesion was performed in order to further characterize the lesion.Non-enhanced axial CT image (Fig. 2) shows a lobulated isoattenuating mass occupying the left renal sinus.Arterial phase axial CT image (Fig. 3) shows a peripheral nodular enhancement of the lesion with early venous drainage (coronal CT image Fig. 5).Persistent peripheral enhancement in the portal venous phase was observed (Fig. 4).Multiple phleboliths are an uncommon finding (salt and pepper sign).


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Cystic renal cell carcinoma
B. Oncocytoma
C. Renal abscess
D. Angiosarcoma
E. Renal haemangioma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: E. Renal haemangioma

Reasoning: The lesion is a lobulated, predominantly cystic mass with thick walls/septa showing peripheral nodular enhancement with early venous drainage and persistent peripheral enhancement—classic for a vascular lesion with centripetal fill-in. The presence of multiple phleboliths ("salt-and-pepper" sign) further supports a venous/vascular malformation/haemangioma rather than abscess, oncocytoma, cystic RCC or angiosarcoma.

## Clinical Case: Case number 11575

### Clinical History
A 54-year-old post-menopausal woman was referred to our institution to perform a hepatobiliary MRI for upper abdominal pain and dyspepsia, occurred in the past year.She had previously undergone a US examination showing a round hypoechoic liver lesion of unclear diagnosis. She reported no relevant medical history.

### Imaging Findings
US presented a 1cm hypoechoic unilocular cyst-like lesion with thin walls, without internal septa, mural nodules or papillary projections, localized in the porta hepatis and showing apparent communication with the common hepatic duct. Doppler evaluation did not demonstrate significant vascularization.MRI images confirmed the presence of a lesion right near the confluence of the right and left hepatic duct. It had a very high signal intensity on T1-weighted images and mild hyperintensity on T2-weighted images; fat-sat images excluded the presence of adipous content. Morphological characteristics of the lesion were similar to US finding with round shape and homogeneous signal.The lesion did not show significant contrast enhancement with a lower signal hyperintensity due to the rescaling phenomenon.Surgical excision was performed and histological diagnosis revealed a well-defined mucinous cystic lesion communicating with the left hepatic duct, composed by a single-layered columnar epithelium with mesenchimal ovarian-like stroma.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Unilocular mucinous cystoadenoma communicating with the left hepatic duct.
B. Focal biliary dilatation
C. Hepatic echinococcal cyst
D. Metastasis from melanoma
E. Intraductal papillary neoplasm of the bile duct

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: A

Reasoning: Middle‑aged woman with a solitary unilocular, non‑enhancing cystic lesion near the hepatic duct that is T1 hyperintense (proteinaceous/mucinous content) and histology showing single‑layered columnar epithelium with ovarian‑type stroma is diagnostic of a mucinous cystic neoplasm (mucinous cystadenoma) of the liver. The ovarian‑like stroma is characteristic and excludes entities such as IPNB, echinococcus, focal biliary dilatation, or metastasis.

## Clinical Case: Case number 11678

### Clinical History
A 45-year-old man presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. A CT Pulmonary Angiogram (CT PA) was ordered for investigation of a pulmonary embolus.

### Imaging Findings
The CT PA showed a hypodense area in the posterobasal segment of the left lower lobe. This area appears to mimic a bullous lesion in emphysema, however, with vessels extending from it (Fig. 1).An abnormal arterial branch originating from the descending thoracic aorta was also evident (Fig. 2). The venous drainage was not appreciable in any of the images. It was not possible to differentiate whether the lesion was intralobar or extralobar.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Congenital pulmonary airway malformation
B. Bronchogenic cyst
C. Pulmonary sequestration
D. Congenital lobar emphysema
E. Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: C

Reasoning: A focal lung lesion in the posterior basal left lower lobe supplied by an anomalous artery arising from the descending thoracic aorta is classic for pulmonary sequestration. The systemic arterial supply (from the aorta) and inability to demonstrate normal bronchial/venous anatomy distinguish sequestration from pulmonary AVM (which is supplied by pulmonary arteries) and from other congenital cystic lesions.

## Clinical Case: Case number 11692

### Clinical History
A 17-year-old male patient presented with a two-day history of periumbilical pain having migrated into the right lower quadrant, associated with vomiting and nausea. ### Imaging Findings
Abdominal sonography showed a hypoechoic tubular 6 mm blind-ending structure in the right lower quadrant, adjacent to the caecum and consistent with a normal appendix (Fig. 1a). A second incompressive tubular structure was visualized in a slightly more cranial location, with a maximal diameter of 17 mm. This second structure contained hyperechoic air as well as hypoechoic debris (Fig. 1b). There were associated enlarged lymph nodes (not shown); no abscess or free air were seen.Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) was then performed, about two hours after oral contrast media administration, showing the second tubular blind-ending structure to be developed from a thickened terminal ileum, with stranding of the surrounding fat and multiple lymph nodes (Fig. 2a, b), consistent with an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum. The appendix and the rest of the abdomen were normal (Fig. 2c).The anatomopathological examination showed acute inflammation, perforation and haemorrhagic changes of the Meckel's diverticulum (Fig. 3).

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

D. Epiploic appendagitis
E. Omental infarction

final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "Ultrasound and CT demonstrate a second blind-ending tubular structure arising from the terminal ileum with air/debris, wall thickening, surrounding fat stranding and enlarged nodes\u2014classic for an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum. Pathology confirmed acute inflammation and perforation. Therefore the correct diagnosis is Meckel's diverticulitis."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 11845

### Clinical History
50-year-old man with lower back pain. MRI ordered to investigate suspected lumbar disc herniation.

### Imaging Findings
MRI of the lumbar spine shows multiple intradural extramedullary masses in the lumbosacral spine. The largest is at L2-L3, sausage-shaped, and measures 11x16x45 mm. Smaller ovoid masses are at L4, L4-L5, and S1. They are heterogeneously hyperintense on T2WI, isointense on T1WI, and intensely enhancing on T1WI C+. They do not protrude into the neural foramina. There are no associated cysts, and there is no associated haemorrhage or scalloping of the vertebral bodies. MRI of the head and complete spine excluded the presence of additional lesions.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Ependymoma
B. Ependymoma (confirmed by pathology)
C. Neurofibroma
D. Drop metastases
E. Schwannoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:

Reasoning: Multiple enhancing intradural extramedullary, sausage‑shaped lesions concentrated in the lumbosacral canal (filum/conus region), T2 hyperintense and intensely enhancing, without foraminal extension, are most typical of a myxopapillary ependymoma (intradural extramedullary ependymoma) with local nodules. Schwannoma/neurofibroma more commonly show foraminal/dumbbell extension or target/plexiform features and NF‑related multiple nerve sheath tumours would usually have additional intracranial/vestibular lesions. Drop metastases are unlikely given no intracranial primary. Pathology was not provided, so pick the imaging diagnosis: ependymoma.

## Clinical Case: Case number 12166

### Clinical History
A man without significant medical history sought medical attention at the emergency department because of changed bowel habits, with unremarkable findings at physical examination and plain abdominal radiographs. The attending surgeon requested prompt investigation with water-enema multidetector CT colonography (WE-CTC).

### Imaging Findings
A day later WE-CTC was performed following limited bowel preparation by means of laxative (sennosides) capsules and magnesium citrate solution. After injection of 20 mg hyoscine N-buthylbromide and retrograde distension with 1 litre of warm tap water, the initial contrast-enhanced CT acquisition (Fig. 1) showed well-distended rectosigmoid and descending colon with thin regular walls and haustra, some endoluminal fecal residues. At the transition between the distal transverse colon and splenic flexure, a nondistensible 4.5 cm segment showed imaging features strongly suggesting carcinoma including solid enhancing circumferential mural thickening, abrupt ��shouldering�� transition distally and proximally, and abundant stools upstream.Without moving the patient from the scanner table, after repeated pharmacological hypotonisation and further rectal water instillation a second CT acquisition (Fig. 2) showed optimal distension of most of the large bowel and disappearance of the above-described finding, consistent with a technical artefact (segmental colonic spasm). Subsequent optical colonoscopy confirmed absence of abnormal colonic changes.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Diverticulitis
B. Extrinsic compression
C. Colon carcinoma
D. Lymphoma

final_response: {"answer": "E", "reasoning": "Initial CT showed a nondistensible short segment with features mimicking carcinoma, but repeat acquisition after further hypotonisation and water instillation showed resolution of the lesion and colonoscopy was normal\u2014consistent with segmental colonic spasm (technical artefact) rather than intrinsic lesion."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 12185

### Clinical History
A 7-year-old girl presented with a large abdominal mass. The mass had been increasing in size over the past month and was associated with abdominal discomfort and weight loss.

### Imaging Findings
Ultrasound of the abdomen showed a large, ill-defined, mixed solid and cystic vascular mass lesion (Fig. 1a-c). On MR imaging, the lesion was demonstrated to have mass effect on adjacent organs. STIR sequence did not show any fat suppression, suggesting that the contents were fluid (Fig. 2a). Coronal (Fig. 2a) and axial (Fig. 2b) T2w images confirmed the mass to be predominantly cystic. The mass was seen displacing adjacent bowel loops and the mesenteric vessels. The stomach was displaced anteriorly, the spleen superiorly and the pancreas to the right side. The location of the mass was presumed in the retroperitoneum. It was seen in close proximity to the left renal artery. The left renal vein was not identified and was possibly compressed or encased by the mass. Severe left hydronephrosis was noted secondary to mass effect on the proximal left ureter (Fig. 2f).


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Liposarcoma
B. Retroperitoneal non-rhabdomyosarcoma soft tissue sarcoma (NRSTS)
C. Desmoid tumour
D. Haemangioendothelioma
E. Neuroblastoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: D

Reasoning: In a young child the combination of a large, ill‑defined, predominantly cystic mass that is Doppler‑vascular and displaces/compresses adjacent retroperitoneal structures is most in keeping with a vascular pediatric tumor such as a haemangioendothelioma. Liposarcoma is excluded by absence of fat; desmoid and NRSTS are typically solid/fibrous rather than predominantly cystic and not markedly vascular; neuroblastoma is usually a solid adrenal/sympathetic chain mass with calcifications and a different age/presentation.

## Clinical Case: Case number 12773

### Clinical History
A 74-year-old male patient presented to our hospital with one month of jaundice, epigastric pain, fever and weight loss. Laboratory examinations revealed anaemia, elevated hepatic enzymes, elevated bilirubin profile that suggested obstructive jaundice and raised CA 19.9 levels.He had a history of cholecystectomy for lithiasis 40 years before.

### Imaging Findings
The patient presented to the hospital complaining of abdominal pain, fever, weight loss and an orange tint of his urine. Blood workup was consistent with obstructive jaundice and ultrasound examination revealed dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts and the common bile duct. He was diagnosed with cholangitis and an elective computed tomography (CT) was ordered.The performed CT scan of the abdomen showed a circumferential, hypovascular and homogeneous wall thickening of the 2nd through the 4th portion of the duodenum of about 20 mm and mucosal folds effacement, suggesting infiltration by a neoplastic process. There were no signs of intestinal obstruction. This duodenal thickening caused biliary and pancreatic ducts dilatation. The circumferential mass did not invade other organs or vessels. Multiple periduodenal and para-aortic adenopathies were also noted.The patient underwent an endoscopic ultrasound and biopsy samples were taken. The histological analysis reported B-cell lymphoma, although a definitive diagnosis was not reached.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Duodenitis
B. Duodenal lymphoma
C. Chronic Crohn\'s disease
D. Metastatic disease
E. Carcinoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: B

Reasoning: CT shows long-segment, circumferential, homogeneous hypovascular thickening of the 2nd–4th portions of the duodenum with mucosal fold effacement, bulky periduodenal/para‑aortic lymphadenopathy, biliary/pancreatic duct dilatation but no invasive behaviour — a pattern typical of gastrointestinal lymphoma. Endoscopic biopsy reporting B‑cell lymphoma further supports the diagnosis. Carcinoma would more often be focal, irregular, heterogeneous and locally invasive; the other options are less consistent with the imaging and biopsy.

## Clinical Case: Case number 13497

### Clinical History
A 83-year-old male patient was admitted in our institution because of cardiogenic shock and 1-day history of chest pain. Bedside echocardiography was performed by the emergency physician and revealed hyperechoic pericardial effusion.

### Imaging Findings
We performed a thoraco-abdominal computed tomography (CT) with the suspicion of aortic dissection. Unenhanced thoracic CT revealed pericardial effusion, with high attenuation (>50 UH) suggesting haemopericardium (Figure 1).Contrast-enhanced thoracic CT at arterial phase showed a defect in the ventricular septum (Figure 2). Thoracic CT with 70 seconds delay demonstrated hypoenhancement in the inferobasal region of the ventricular septum, where the rupture was seen, consistent with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) (Figure 3).Contrast-enhanced abdominal CT also showed contrast reflux into hepatic veins suggesting right-ventricular failure (Figure 4).

### Options
A. Ventricular septal rupture.
B. Ventricular free wall rupture
C. Left ventricular aneursym
D. Aortic dissection
E. Papillary muscle rupture

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: A

Reasoning: Contrast CT demonstrates a clear defect in the ventricular septum with surrounding hypoenhancement consistent with acute infarction of the inferobasal septum — findings diagnostic of a postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (VSR). Associated high‑attenuation pericardial fluid and hepatic venous contrast reflux reflect the acute hemodynamic compromise, but the visible septal defect differentiates VSR from free‑wall rupture, papillary muscle rupture, aneurysm or aortic dissection.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

B. Lymphangioma

## Clinical Case: Case number 15136

### Clinical History
A 26-year-old male resident doctor presented with decreased sensation and pain in his thumb, index and middle finger of right hand since one month. His symptoms aggravated during sports involving continuous hand movements, such as badminton. On examination, there was hypoesthesia in the median nerve distribution.

### Imaging Findings
Initially, X-ray is advised for the right wrist, and it showed no obvious abnormality (Fig. 1).Also a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study of right hand with wrist was completed, and it revealed an intraneural lesion measuring approximately 10 x 5 mm with intralesional bleed in the median nerve in the carpal tunnel region. The lesion demonstrated iso to high signal intensity on T1W and hyperintensity on T2W and STIR sequences (Fig. 2, 3, and 4). On gradient echo image blooming was seen within the lesion suggestive of intralesional bleed (Fig. 5). On post-contrast examination, lesion showed significant heterogeneous enhancement (Fig. 6).On histopathology the lesion was composed of intercommunicating ecstatic venous channels separated by thin fibrous stroma (Fig. 8). The lesion also showed medium to large cavernous spaces lined by a single layer of flattened endothelial cells with RBC's in lumen [2] (Fig. 9). Verhoeff-van Gieson stain for elastic fibres was negative (Fig. 10). Hence it was confirmed to be intraneural venous malformation of the median nerve [1].


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Intraneural venous malformation of the median nerve [1].
B. Fibrolipoma of median nerve
C. Intraneural haemangioma
D. Schwannoma
E. Peripheral nerve sheath tumour

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: A

Reasoning: MRI shows an intraneural, enhancing lesion in the median nerve with intralesional hemorrhage (GRE blooming) and clinical median neuropathy. Histology demonstrates dilated intercommunicating venous channels/cavernous spaces lined by flattened endothelium and absence of elastic fibers — findings diagnostic of an intraneural venous malformation (venous-type vascular malformation), rather than lipomatous, schwannomatous, or arterial/hemangiomatous tumors.

Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy (FNAC) was inconclusive due to the scarce amount of acquired material, however, no signs of atypia were found. Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was thus requested by the referring physician. The examination confirmed the presence of an ovoid, well-marginated lesion in the deep lobe of the left parotid gland, measuring 8x11x16mm. The tumour was heterogeneous, predominantly hypointense on T1-weighted images (T1-WI), hyperintense on T2-WI and fat-saturated T2-WI (Figs. 1a-c). Signs of restriction of diffusion were present with Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC) value of1.0x10-3mm2/sec(Figs. 2a,b). Lesion enhanced vividly and on the basis of dynamic contrast-enhanced sequence type"b��Time-intensity Curve (TiC) was obtained (Fig. 3). No signs of facial nerve involvement or perineurial spread were noted. Regional lymph nodes were not enlarged.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Whartin Tumor
B. Salivary Gland Acinic Cell Carcinoma
C. Acinic Cell Carcinoma
D. Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma (low grade tumor)
E. Parotid Benign Mixed Tumor

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: A

Reasoning: Well-circumscribed, hypervascular parotid lesion with vivid enhancement and diffusion restriction (ADC ≈1.0 ×10^-3 mm2/s) is most typical of a Warthin tumour. Pleomorphic (benign mixed) tumours usually have very high T2 signal, higher ADC and progressive enhancement. Acinic cell or mucoepidermoid carcinoma are less likely given the benign-appearing margins, lack of perineural/ nodal disease and the characteristic low ADC/rapid enhancement pattern favouring Warthin.

## Clinical Case: Case number 17406

### Clinical History
A 59 year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of dyspnea and fatigue after two episodes of alimentary vomits. Past medical history included epiglottis cancer, hepatitis B, COVID-19 and pulmonary tuberculosis. Physical examination revealed signs of mild dehydration. Blood tests revealed leucocitosis (12300 cells/mm3) and C-Reactive protein of 11.19 mg/L. She was admitted with a presumed diagnosis of bacterial gastroenteritis complicated with dehydration, oral intolerance and acute renal failure and initiated empiric antibiotic therapy (ciprofloxacin).

### Imaging Findings
Chest X-ray revealed small nodular opacities bilaterally, probable tuberculous granulomas. Abdominal ultrasound showed signs of chronic hepatopathy and a thin left peri-renal fluid layer.On day 2 of admission with a presumed diagnosis of bacterial gastroenteritis she showed signs of respiratory distress and abdominal distention. Repeated chest X-ray (Fig. 1) revealed massive pneumoperitoneum. Abdominal X-ray (Fig. 2) showed a gas-fluid level, also shown on ultrasound as intra-abdominal gas centrally and moderate volume of peritoneal fluid.Subsequent computer tomography (CT) detected a large pneumoperitoneum and a moderate quantity of free fluid (Figs. 3,4). A small discontinuity in the anterior aspect of the duodenal bulb and adjacent wall thickening and edema were found, highly suggestive of duodenal perforation.Urgent surgical intervention confirmed a perforated justapyloric ulcer measuring 1,5 cm in the first portion of duodenum with ischemic borders. A pyloroplasty and peritoneal lavage were done. Afterwards, she developed signs of septic chock and ischemic hepatitis and despite optimal supportive and therapeutic measures she passed away at day 3 of admission.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Hydropneumoperitoneum secondary to duodenal ulcer perforation
B. Gastrointestinal perforation secondary to inflammatory or neoplasic condition
C. Idiopathic spontaneous pneumoperitoneum
D. Gastrointestinal perforation secondary to ingested foreign body
E. Gastrointestinal perforation secondary to bowel ischemia

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "CT and radiographs demonstrate massive pneumoperitoneum with gas\u2013fluid level and a focal discontinuity in the anterior duodenal bulb with adjacent wall thickening/edema \u2014 findings most consistent with perforation of a duodenal (juxtapyloric) peptic ulcer. Intraoperative confirmation of a 1.5 cm perforated juxta\u2011pyloric ulcer with ischemic borders further supports this. Other options (idiopathic pneumoperitoneum, foreign body, ischemic bowel, or neoplastic/inflammatory causes) are less likely given the focal duodenal defect and surgical findings."}

## Clinical Case: Case number 9246

### Clinical History
54-year-old woman attended the emergency department complaining of rectal bleeding.The blood test showed significant anaemia.In the upper endoscopy a clot was visualized on the descending duodenal portion with an ulcerous injury and adjacent inflammatory changes.The colonoscopy did not show relevant findings.Urgent surgery was required because of hypovolemia.

In the unenhanced CT several calcium density images on mesentery can be observed (calcified adenopathies).In the contrast enhanced CT a hypodense lesion at the duodenum wall, contrast extravasation towards the intestinal lumen (compatible with active bleeding) and remarkable inflammatory changes in the mesentery fat can be shown. Extraluminal gas bubbles are also seen (pneumoperitoneum). Between the duodenum and right colon a tubular hypodense image can be observed, that could correspond to a fistulous tract.On the surgery a 3cm lesion was found on the antimesenteric border of duodenum with intraluminal growth and border bleeding.The hysthologic result showed: inflammatory granulomatous reaction in the duodenal lesion and extirpated adenopathies, necrotic areas in some adenopathies and flat ulcerations surrounded by granulomatous lesions at the duodenal mucosa. The findings were compatible with tuberculous etiology.After surgery the patient was treated with antituberculous drugs and controlled at the Department of Infectious Disease.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

B. Crohn\'s disease

final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "CT showed calcified mesenteric lymphadenopathy and inflammatory changes; surgery revealed an ulcerated duodenal lesion with possible fistula; histology demonstrated granulomatous inflammation with necrosis in nodes and duodenal mucosa \u2014 findings most consistent with intestinal tuberculosis. ## Clinical Case: Case number 9299

### Clinical History
61-years-old male patient undergoing chronic highly active antiretroviral treatment (HAART) for long-standing HIV infection (CD4+ cell count 250/mmc).Recurrent,  progressively more severe episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhoea with blood-stained stools over the last three months,  ultimately leading to hospitalisation.

### Imaging Findings
Laboratory assays disclosed anaemia (Hb 7.1 g/dL) and mildly raised C-reactive Protein (20). Emergency CT examination yielded diffuse concentric wall thickening of the caecum,ascending colon and hepatic flexure showing the target sign consistent with mural oedema and inflammation. The terminal ileum was spared from pathologic changes. Associated findings included moderately ascites and inflammatory stranding of the right pericolonic fat. Significant adenopathies,  focal liver or spleen lesions were not detected.Microscopy and cultures on stools and blood were negative for bacteria (particularly Shigella and Clostridium difficile),mycobacteria,fungi and toxins. Positive serum antibodies for Entamoeba allowed a clinical diagnosis of amoebic colitis and antibiotic treatment was prescribed.After 3 months,follow-up CT disclosed disappearance of both ascites and mural colonic abnormalities,thus confirming the clinical diagnosis.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis
B. Crohn��s disease
C. Amoebic colitis
D. Typhlitis
E. Ulcerative colitis

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: C

Reasoning: Imaging shows circumferential (target sign) thickening limited to the right colon (caecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure) with ascites and pericolonic stranding, while the terminal ileum is spared. Stool cultures were negative and Entamoeba serology was positive; the colitis resolved on follow-up CT after treatment. The combination of right-sided colonic involvement, ascites, positive Entamoeba serology and radiologic resolution after therapy is most consistent with amoebic colitis. Other options (CMV, Crohn's, typhlitis, ulcerative colitis) are less compatible with the distribution, clinical context and response.

## Clinical Case: Case number 9435

### Clinical History
An 11-year-old boy who lived on a farm presented with a 2-week history of fever, vomiting and pain in the right hip that extended into the right buttock. The patient was non-weight bearing on the right leg, with restricted movement of the right hip. CRP was elevated.

### Imaging Findings
The pelvic radiograph (Fig. 1) at presentation was normal. Clinical examination had revealed tenderness on deep palpation of the right iliac fossa, and an abdominal ultrasound obtained to exclude appendicitis was negative. No hip joint effusion was seen on ultrasound. A MRI examination (Fig. 2) was requested. Axial and coronal STIR and T2w images showed a focal lesion with surrounding high signal in the right sacral alum and less well-defined high signal in the right iliac bone also. The sacral lesion was associated with cortical loss at the inferior aspect of the right sacroiliac joint and a low signal (all sequences) central bony sequestrum. The adjacent iliacus, pectineus, obturator internus, psoas and gluteus maximus muscles were thickened and of high signal. There was marked enhancement post-gadolinium of the bony sacral lesion and the anterior soft tissue collection. A subsequent limited-range CT examination (Fig. 3) showed the sacral abnormalities in more detail.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Brucellosis
B. Pyogenic osteomyelitis - Staphylococcus aureus
C. Sacral osteomyelitis with associated pyogenic sacral osteomyelitis.
D. Genitourinary tract or abdomen and pelvis
E. Sickle cell disease

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: B

Reasoning: Imaging shows focal marrow signal abnormality of the right sacral ala with cortical destruction and a central low‑signal sequestrum plus marked adjacent muscle edema/collection (iliacus, psoas, obturator internus, gluteal muscles) and contrast enhancement—findings typical of pyogenic osteomyelitis with secondary soft‑tissue abscess. In children the common pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus. Brucellar sacroiliitis is possible with farm exposure but usually produces joint erosions/arthritic change rather than a sequestrum and aggressive adjacent soft‑tissue abscesses.

## Clinical Case: Case number 9556

### Clinical History
A 5-year-old boy with no relevant personal or family medical history was admitted at the emergency department with dysuria and hypogastric pain with 24 hours of evolution. On physical examination a hard painful mass in the right flank and right iliac fossa was noted and therefore the patient underwent abdominal ultrasound and CT.

### Imaging Findings
Abdominal sonography demonstrated a solid heterogeneous well-defined mass, without calcification, with small cystic areas, located above the bladder.Abdominal CT showed a large lobulated, soft tissue density mass in the pelvic region. The mass was heterogeneous, with extensive hypodense areas reflecting necrosis. No evidence of calcification was seen in the lesion. The mass extended from the aortic bifurcation making contact with the bladder, but without definite signs of invasion. There were no signs of bone invasion. Both kidneys were normal.The following complementary exams were performed: Tru-cut biopsy (inconclusive), tumour markers - alpha-fetoprotein, beta-HCG - and urinary catecholamines (normal), bone scintigraphy (normal) and myelogram (normal).Since the results were inconclusive the child underwent surgical biopsy and the diagnosis of extrarenal nephroblastoma was established.Surgical resection, chemotherapy and neoadjuvant radiotherapy were performed.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Neuroblastoma
B. Rhabdomyosarcoma
C. Extrarenal Wilms' tumour
D. Lymphoma
E. Germ cell tumour of extragonadal origin

final_response: {"answer": "C", "reasoning": "A 5-year-old with a large lobulated pelvic/retroperitoneal mass contacting the bladder but with normal kidneys, heterogeneous with necrosis and no calcification, and normal AFP/\u03b2-hCG and urinary catecholamines is most consistent with extrarenal Wilms' tumour (nephroblastoma). ## Clinical Case: Case number 9823

### Clinical History
A 51-year-old female patient presented to our department with a large tumour mass on her left upper eyelid, purple, rapidly growing and not painful. She could not open the eye completely but motor and visual functions were preserved. The lesion had appeared two months before and had been initially diagnosed as a chalazion.

### Imaging Findings
The CT examination performed after administration of contrast medium shows a solid and roundish formation of 25 x 18 mm in the left upper eyelid; positive lymph nodes are not documented.In view of the suspected diagnosis of malignant tumour, a biopsy was performed under local anaesthesia.The MR examination demonstrated an exophytic lesion with signs of haemorrhage inside, in relation to the previous biopsy; the lesion appears markedly hydrated with smooth and regular margins and the eyeball does not seem to be infiltrated.The tumour tissue immunohistochemical study proved positive for neuronal specific enolase (NSE), sinaptofisina, CD56, PAN-CK and CK AE1/AE3.However, imaging characteristics are aspecific and the role of imaging is limited to the description of extension of the lesion as to the eyebal, pre and postseptal fat planes, lacrimal gland and temporal muscle.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Skin metastases of small cell carcinoma
B. Angiosarcoma
C. Neuroblastoma
D. Keratoacanthoma
E. Merkel cell carcinoma

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response:
Answer: E

Reasoning: Rapidly growing purple eyelid nodule in an adult combined with positive neuroendocrine markers (NSE, synaptophysin, CD56) and epithelial cytokeratins (PAN‑CK, CK AE1/AE3) is characteristic of cutaneous neuroendocrine (Merkel cell) carcinoma. Other options are less likely: metastatic small‑cell carcinoma would typically show markers (e.g. TTF‑1) suggesting a pulmonary primary, neuroblastoma is a paediatric tumour, angiosarcoma shows vascular markers (CD31/ERG) and keratoacanthoma is a squamous lesion with different histology.

## Clinical Case: Case number 9905

### Clinical History
A 66-year-old woman with previous thyroidectomy for follicular carcinoma of the thyroid gland presented with a painless swelling in the right cheek, gradually growing in size over the previous two months. Physical examination revealed a palpable mass with no associated skin changes or superficial lesions. No neck nodes were palpable.

An orthopantomography showed a large expansive lesion in the right side of the mandible with lytic characteristics.A head and neck CT without contrast medium (Fig. 1) showed a 4 x 5.5 cm mass lesion situated in the right masticatory space, originating from the posterior mandibular ramus. The mass was cystic with a unilocular pattern and scalloped borders associated with thinning and defects of the bone cortex.An MRI with contrast medium (Fig. 2) was performed in order to better evaluate the morphology of the lesion. The lesion showed a high signal intensity in T2 weighted sequences and low signal intensity in T1 weighted sequences, due to fluid content. It had a cyst-like appearance with an enhancing peripheral rim showing an intramural enhancing soft tissue nodule on the medial aspect of the cystic wall.

Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Odontogenic keratocyst (keratocystic odontogenic tumour)
B. Ameloblastoma
C. Ameloblastoma
D. Dentigerous cyst
E. Metastatic lesion of follicular carcinoma of the thyroid gland

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "E", "reasoning": "History of prior follicular thyroid carcinoma and age (66) raise strong suspicion for metastasis to the mandible. Imaging shows a large lytic, expansile unilocular cystic lesion with cortical defects and an enhancing intramural soft\u2011tissue nodule \u2014 a pattern compatible with metastatic tumor with central necrosis and an enhancing mural component. ### Clinical History
Female patient, 81-year-old, admitted 4 days previously with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), on oxygen therapy and intravenous antibiotics. ### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

final_response: {"answer": "D", "reasoning": "Imaging demonstrates a duodenal wall defect with oral contrast opacifying a paravertebral collection that tracks into the intervertebral spaces and anterior epidural space, proving direct enteric perforation/fistulisation to the spine. Tuberculosis and fungal infection are less likely given the acute presentation, imaging with oral contrast demonstrating enteric fistula, and positive blood cultures for S. anginosus. ## Clinical Case: Case number 16760

### Clinical History
60-year old female patient, non-smoker, was referred to the Department of Otolaryngology with left parotid gland tumour. The lesion was incidentally found during thyroid ultrasound (surveillance due to hypothyroidism). The patient was asymptomatic.

### Imaging Findings
The lesion was reported on ultrasound as solid, hypoechoic and hypervascular. Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy (FNAC) was inconclusive due to the scarce amount of acquired material, however, no signs of atypia were found. Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was thus requested by the referring physician. The examination confirmed the presence of an ovoid, well-marginated lesion in the deep lobe of the left parotid gland, measuring 8x11x16mm. The tumour was heterogeneous, predominantly hypointense on T1-weighted images (T1-WI), hyperintense on T2-WI and fat-saturated T2-WI (Figs. 1a-c). Signs of restriction of diffusion were present with Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC) value of1.0x10-3mm2/sec(Figs. 2a,b). Lesion enhanced vividly and on the basis of dynamic contrast-enhanced sequence type"b��Time-intensity Curve (TiC) was obtained (Fig. 3). No signs of facial nerve involvement or perineurial spread were noted. Regional lymph nodes were not enlarged.


### Question
Based on the clinical history and imaging findings above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

### Options
A. Whartin Tumor
B. Salivary Gland Acinic Cell Carcinoma
C. Acinic Cell Carcinoma
D. Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma (low grade tumor)
E. Parotid Benign Mixed Tumor

Please analyze this case and select the correct answer (A, B, C, D, or E).
final_response: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "Most likely diagnosis: Warthin tumour. Reasoning: The lesion is a small, well-marginated, T1-hypo / T2-hyperintense, vividly enhancing parotid mass with restricted diffusion (ADC ~1.0 x10^-3 mm2/s) and a Type\u2011B time\u2013intensity curve (early peak enhancement with rapid washout). This combination (low ADC + rapid washout on dynamic contrast imaging) is characteristic of Warthin tumour and helps differentiate it from pleomorphic adenoma (benign mixed tumour), which typically shows progressive/late enhancement (Type\u2011A curve) and higher ADC values. Acinic cell and mucoepidermoid carcinomas are less likely given the small, well-circumscribed appearance, lack of perineural/nodal disease and the classic dynamic/ADC profile. Supporting literature/cases from the database (e.g. Eurorad case 11031) describe Warthin tumours with early intense enhancement and rapid washout and cystic/oncocytic features on imaging, consistent with this case."}

Finally, artero-venous malformation was confirmed on histologic evaluation (Fig.5).

### Clinical History
An 11-year-old boy who lived on a farm presented with a 2-week history of fever, vomiting and pain in the right hip that extended into the right buttock. The patient was non-weight bearing on the right leg, with restricted movement of the right hip. CRP was elevated.

The pelvic radiograph (Fig. 1) at presentation was normal. The sacral lesion was associated with cortical loss at the inferior aspect of the right sacroiliac joint and a low signal (all sequences) central bony sequestrum. The adjacent iliacus, pectineus, obturator internus, psoas and gluteus maximus muscles were thickened and of high signal. There was marked enhancement post-gadolinium of the bony sacral lesion and the anterior soft tissue collection. final_response: {"answer": "B", "reasoning": "Acute presentation with fever, elevated CRP and MRI/CT findings of a focal sacral bone lesion with cortical loss, a central low-signal sequestrum and extensive adjacent muscle/soft-tissue high-signal and an enhancing fluid collection are classic for pyogenic osteomyelitis with intraosseous abscess and soft-tissue extension.
